McIntyre's legal team in Belfast is also preparing to file papers in the High Court, challenging the legality of a decision by the Public Prosecution Service (PPS) to use an international treaty to seek help from US authorities. It orders a representative of the college to appear in court in Massachusetts on the following Friday and provide the requested information. McIntyre's legal team claims that this request is unlawful. What are the 'Boston tapes'? The Welsh full-back, Davies, 21, has signed a five-year contract with Tottenham, joining the Londoners from his club, Wales. The Netherlands goalkeeper, Vorm, 30, has agreed a four-year deal with the Londoners, after Tottenham reportedly fought off stiff competition for Davies. The Icelandic international midfielder, Sigurdsson, 24, has signed a four-year deal with Swansea, after spending 2011-12 on loan from German club Hoffenheim, scoring seven goals in 18 appearances. Tottenham is believed to have won the race for Davies, with Liverpool's boss, Brendan Rodgers, rumored to be a fan. However, Davies stated that Tottenham had shown interest from the beginning and that the opportunity to join the north London club was too good to pass up.

A pricing regulator in Jiangsu has declared that a luxury German automaker has coerced local dealers into setting a minimum sales price for certain of its car models. Some local dealers have also been fined 7.7 million yuan, according to regulators. Mercedes-Benz has stated that it accepts the decision and takes competition law very seriously, adding that it has taken all necessary steps to ensure full compliance with the law. According to a statement from the Chinese regulator, an investigation found that Mercedes-Benz and its dealers in Jiangsu had entered into monopoly agreements to cap the lowest sales prices of certain E-Class and S-Class models as well as spare parts. Last year, Xinhua reported that Mercedes had also been found guilty of manipulating the prices of after-sales services in China. China is the world's largest car market, attracting foreign automakers.

S4C primarily generates income through the license fee, and UK ministers have recently announced a significant review of the BBC. Monmouth MP David Davies, speaking on BBC Wales, stated that S4C is a "special case" as it supports the Welsh language. Ministers have advised S4C to pursue similar cost savings as the BBC. On Thursday, the Labour Party warned that cuts to the BBC's budget could threaten S4C. However, the Culture Secretary, John Whittingdale, assured MPs that there is a commitment to S4C within the next few years and he hopes to have discussions with its management in the near future. Davies, in an interview with BBC Radio Cymru's Rhaglen Dylan Jones, highlighted that the government recognizes the significance of S4C and its role in the future of the Welsh language. Davies also hinted that the Welsh Affairs Committee, of which he is the chair, might consider conducting an inquiry into broadcasting, including S4C. The remains of a woman were discovered at Cockley Cley, near Swaffham in Norfolk in August 1974. The Norfolk Police conducted a second post-mortem examination using modern techniques to analyze the DNA. Det Ch Insp Andy Guy expressed the possibility of linking the woman to a living family member through the recovered DNA evidence. The first examination, which was conducted on the day of the discovery, estimated the woman's age between 23 and 35. She was found wearing a 1969 pink Marks & Spencer nightdress and wrapped in a plastic sheet secured with ropes. The primary line of inquiry is that she could have been an escort known as The Duchess from Great Yarmouth. The Duchess was well-known in the local area, but she disappeared suddenly and was believed to be from Denmark.

The research compared individuals who were undergoing intense military cadet training to those whose living conditions remained stable. During the training, participants demonstrated a preference for heavier-looking individuals. Lead researcher Dr. Carlota Batres suggested that men's preferences may change in challenging environments so that they can mate with women who are best suited for survival and reproduction. "Our findings provide new evidence for the malleability of preferences in relation to the environment," she said. "We found that the weight preferences in potential female partners changed in response to the harsher environment and then remained at the new level even when the environment remained harsh. "Such changes in preferences may be advantageous as they allow for increased opportunities to form partnerships with individuals who are better equipped to survive illness or uncertain food availability." Participants were asked to rate the attractiveness of various individuals based on their physical appearance.

In a statement, it was announced that Foreign Affairs Secretary Perfecto Yasay would raise the issue at a significant two-day Asia-Europe Summit, starting on Friday. This summit, attended by China's Premier Li Keqiang, will bring together 53 leaders from Asia and Europe, including countries such as Vietnam and Malaysia, who also claim territory in the region. This summit will be the first major multilateral diplomatic gathering since the 12th of July ruling over the South China Sea. Despite a UN-backed tribunal ruling on Tuesday that there is no legal basis for China's claims in the South China Sea, China has vowed to ignore the ruling. The Chinese government maintains that the tribunal has no jurisdiction over the issue, and its activities in the region will not be affected.

John McCormack continued driving for an additional 30 miles in the articulated lorry after the incident involving the other vehicle on the A9. Perth Sheriff Court was informed that there were three children in the car at the time of the accident. The 46-year-old was ordered to complete 250 hours of unpaid work and was banned from driving for two years. A prosecutor, Rebecca Kynaston, explained that motorists heading north near the House of Bruar shopping complex witnessed McCormack driving towards them on the wrong side of the road. She stated, "To their horror, they saw the lorry coming south. They managed to get off the road onto the verge, but unfortunately, the lorry hit the offside of the car and scraped along."

In a supporters' poll, a Seattle Reign player secured the second BBC World Service award, following in the footsteps of the first winner. She defeated competitors like Gaelle Enganamouit (FC Rosengard, Sweden), Amandine Henry (Olympique Lyonnais), Carli Lloyd (Houston Dash), and Becky Sauerbrunn (FC Kansas City). The surprised winner expressed her gratitude, stating that women's football is thriving and hopes for continued progress. The award was presented at the club's training facility, with Mary Hockaday, the Controller of BBC World Service English, expressing her pride in Kim Little's accomplishments and the importance of recognizing female footballers.

Some patients at Stafford Hospital had to drink water from vases because the care was not good. People who worked at the hospital, like receptionists, were also not doing their jobs right. Julie Bailey, who started a group called "Cure the NHS" after watching her mom get treated there, was given a special honor called a CBE. Helene Donnelly, a nurse who spoke up about the bad care, was given an honor called an OBE. It was said that more people died at the hospital than expected between 2005 and 2008. People in pain did not get help in time, and food and drinks were kept far away from them. Helene Donnelly worked at the emergency department of the hospital. She told about 100 problems with the care of patients, became a whistleblower, and was an important witness at a public inquiry. She was very proud and honored to get an OBE for helping the National Health Service, even though it was a very hard time.

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has stated that certain credit card customers are profitable for providers and there have been limited incentives for firms to intervene on their behalf. The FCA has recommended that customers should aim to pay off more of their debt whenever possible. The inquiry, which has analyzed the credit card usage of 34 million customers over a five-year period, has also interviewed 40,000 people about their credit card use. 

The interim findings of the FCA inquiry show that, while there is strong competition for some customers and products, other customers are not being targeted by providers. The FCA has found that providers are quick to intervene when customers miss payments, as these customers are considered "extremely unprofitable." However, the same level of intervention is not applied to customers who are struggling to make ends meet. 

Joanna Elson, CEO of the Money Advice Trust, which runs the National Debtline, has expressed support for the FCA's concerns about 1.6 million people who are barely managing to survive by making only minimum payments, often on multiple credit cards. According to Elson, credit card companies should be more proactive in helping these customers manage their debt.

According to the Bank's financial stability director, Alex Brazier, outstanding car loans, credit card balance transfers, and personal loans have increased by 10% over the past year. In contrast, household incomes have risen by only 1.5%. Brazier stated, "Household debt - like most things that are good in moderation - can be dangerous in excess." He further elaborated in a speech at the University of Liverpool's Institute for Risk and Uncertainty, emphasizing that the rise in debt is "dangerous to borrowers, lenders, and, most importantly from our perspective, everyone else in the economy." Brazier warned that High Street banks could fall into a state of complacency regarding the mounting consumer debt levels. He also noted that lending standards can change rapidly from responsible to reckless. According to Brazier, as lenders perceive risks to be declining, the actual risks they and the wider economy face are growing. He hinted that the Bank of England may need to intervene to prevent potential issues in the financial sector.

David Dallimore, a child care and early years researcher at Bangor University, proposes a comprehensive reform of early childhood education for children aged three to four. He believes that Wales has not been able to develop a long-term vision for early years services and emphasizes the need for a strategic approach. The Welsh government, however, needs more information on the proposed Childcare Bill before considering its options. At present, all three and four-year-olds in Wales are entitled to at least 10 hours of education through the Foundation Phase. The 22 councils have the autonomy to choose how these hours are delivered and the amount spent on them, leading to significant variations in the level and flexibility of services across the country.

The removal of the engines, which have been inactive for two years, would leave 142 active vehicles in the capital. Savings from this proposal would be invested in increasing the number of staff available to crew Fire Rescue Units. However, the Fire Brigades Union (FBU) claims that getting rid of them permanently would be "dangerous and reckless." The London Fire Brigade (LFB) has proposed three plans to make the necessary savings. The LFB insists that no stations will close and no firefighters will be forced to leave their jobs. The Brigade has maintained compliance with London-wide attendance time targets while the 13 engines were out of service, and bringing them back would improve response times by about four seconds for the first engine to reach the scene. A counterproposal was put forward by London Assembly Member Andrew Dismore.

The CEO of Charter NI, a prominent member of the UDA, has faced criticism for comments made to The Guardian. In response, the board of Charter NI expressed disappointment and concern about the article. However, they stated that they are handling the matter internally. In the article, Mr. Stitt referred to the loyalist band North Down Defenders as "our homeland security" and claimed that the government does not care about Northern Ireland. The Northern Ireland Executive awarded a £1.7m grant to Charter NI, which is a community-based organization. SDLP MLA Nichola Mallon stated that Mr. Stitt's position with Charter NI is no longer tenable, and that he should resign immediately. The board of Charter NI confirmed that Mr. Stitt remains the CEO of the organization.

A PC named Frances Tilley admitted that she had "ruined" her career after not paying for a trip between Bristol Temple Meads and Castle Cary in Somerset last June. She was less than two years into her job and still in probation. She was dismissed for serious misconduct. The disciplinary hearing at Northamptonshire Police headquarters was held at Wootton Hall. Tilley traveled from Northampton to Castle Cary on June 22nd last year. The officer, described as "diligent, professional, and committed," was traveling with friends and did not buy a ticket for the final leg of the journey. The force solicitor, Elizabeth Briggs, said, "She traveled from Bristol to Westbury and then to Castle Cary. At that point, she did not have a valid ticket for the trip. There were opportunities for her to buy a ticket. She said it was her first time traveling without a ticket."

It is said that the robbery occurred on a Sunday morning at a jewelry exhibition held at the Carlton Hotel. The hotel is located in one of the most prestigious areas of the town, the Croisette promenade. The theft is part of a series of high-profile robberies that have occurred in Cannes, which is known for its annual film festival. The Carlton Hotel is where Alfred Hitchcock filmed "To Catch a Thief" in 1955. This latest robbery involved an exhibition of diamonds by the jeweler Leviev, which was taking place in the lobby of the hotel. According to local media, the robber made off with the jewels in a briefcase. The owner of the jewels has not yet been identified, and if the value is confirmed, it would reportedly be the second-largest heist in France. A spokesman for the Cannes police stated.

The Spurs team suffered a 1-0 loss in their most recent European game at the national stadium. This season, the club has now lost both European games at their home venue, White Hart Lane, which is currently undergoing renovations. Manager Pochettino expressed that playing at Wembley, their temporary home stadium for Champions League games, is not a disadvantage as they are the ones struggling, not the venue. Next season, Spurs have the option to play all home league and cup matches, as well as any European games, at Wembley. Pochettino acknowledged the team's poor performance, stating that there is no excuse and they need to find the solution within themselves. He emphasized that the team is disappointed and cannot showcase the recent successful performances, which is a significant concern.

During a BBC debate about the upcoming EU referendum held at the University of Lincoln, a participant remarked, "I'm neutral, but I'm being bombarded by half-truths, lies, and scare tactics from both sides." The panel, which will air on Sunday, included UKIP MEP Jane Collins for Leave, Labour MP Melanie Onn for Remain, and journalist Robin Limb. One of the topics discussed was the NHS and its connection to the EU. Yorkshire and Humber MEP Ms. Collins stated, "We contribute £675 million annually to the EU, which is invested in other countries' healthcare programs. In return, we only receive £49 million back, which is an injustice. We must leave to regain control of our NHS." She added that it should be "easier for nurses to become qualified within the country" and that all NHS workers should receive "reasonable pay for a day's work." In contrast, MP Melanie Onn argued that it is "far more likely" that remaining in the EU would be advantageous.

A hotel owner named Ranjit Singh Power from Wolverhampton disappeared last year during a business trip to the Punjab. A taxi driver has admitted to his murder, but local police suspect that he may not have acted alone. The victim's family is desperate for answers and are struggling to obtain information from the Foreign Office and other officials in India. Ranjit's brother, Amrik Singh Power, has been contacting these officials, but feels as though he is not receiving any responses to his inquiries. The last known whereabouts of Ranjit were at an airport in Amritsar on May 8th. His family reported him missing after a week with no contact.

The University of Birmingham recently disclosed a significant discovery in July, revealing that the ancient manuscript dates back at least 1,370 years. Susan Worrall, a University of Birmingham representative, described the manuscript as a "global treasure." Currently on display at the Edgbaston campus until October 25th, the manuscript is free for visitors to see. The pages of this Muslim holy text had been unnoticed in the university library for nearly a century. One visitor expressed their amazement, stating that this manuscript might have been touched by Prophet Muhammad or the greatest men in their religion. Director of Special Collections, Ms. Worrall, said, "It has been fantastically exciting to find out we have one of the oldest fragments of the Koran in the world." The local Muslim community has expressed joy and appreciation for this remarkable discovery.

Yorkshire batsman Joe Root has recently been appointed as the new Test captain following Alastair Cook's resignation after more than four years in charge. Root emphasizes the importance of winning games while also emphasizing the need for England's performances to be enjoyable. Root's first match as England captain is against South Africa at Lord's on July 7th. The 26-year-old has moved up from his previous role as vice-captain, with Durham all-rounder Ben Stokes taking on the role of his deputy. Stokes, 25, is eager to help England regain their former glory in Test cricket. "We need to win but we want to perform in a manner that makes people want to come and watch us," Stokes said. "Test cricket is the pinnacle, and we need people to fall in love with it again," he added. Discussing his elevation to vice-captain, Stokes said: "Everything I do is to win and being vice-captain won't change me as a person or as a player. I want to be involved in all aspects of the game, whether it's hitting the winning runs or taking the final wicket. I have always wanted to be in a leadership role and I am excited for this new challenge."

Today, India rests in peace, as you stand watch throughout the night. Speaking to soldiers stationed at Siachen, Prime Minister Modi expressed his gratitude for their dedication. Contested by both India and Pakistan, Siachen is known as the highest battlefield in the world. Later, Mr. Modi traveled to the Kashmir valley, where floods had tragically claimed over 280 lives and left Srinagar underwater. More than a million people were displaced as a result. This marks the second time an Indian Prime Minister has visited Siachen, with Manmohan Singh making the journey in 2005. Despite the harsh conditions, more soldiers have died from weather-related incidents than in combat since India took control of Siachen in 1984. Deployed at heights of up to 22,000 feet above sea level, Mr. Modi met with senior officials and aid workers to review relief efforts during the Diwali festival, India's largest Hindu celebration. The devastating floods in Indian-administered Kashmir had damaged nearly 180,000 homes, leaving many people still living in relief camps.

The world-renowned club in Elephant and Castle, located in southeastern London, has been trying to prevent the construction of a multi-story apartment building adjacent to its premises. The club's management is worried that noise complaints from nearby residents could lead to its closure. Initially, Southwark Council denied planning permission for the project. However, this decision was later reversed by Prime Minister Boris Johnson. It was revealed that some Liberal Democrat council members had accepted substantial donations from the club, which were not declared at the meeting. Neither the Labour councillors nor the developer Oakmayne were aware of these undisclosed donations. The club and the Liberal Democrats maintain that their actions were lawful.

The proposed amendments would permit Japanese troops to engage in international conflicts for the first time since World War II. The legislation has already been passed by Japan's lower house and is anticipated to be supported by the upper chamber. Under its constitution, Japan is prohibited from using force to address conflicts except in cases of self-defense. However, a reinterpretation of the law will now permit "collective self-defense" - using force to protect allies under attack. To minimize disruptions in the capital's center, police have been lining the streets and urging protesters to relocate. Despite the rainy weather, tens of thousands of protesters have flooded the streets, demanding that their pacifist constitution be preserved and calling for the resignation of the prime minister. The streets were lined with police vans, but given how rare it is for the Japanese to be so vocal, there was no fear that things would escalate. These protests have been ongoing throughout the summer, largely led by concerned citizens.

The individual declared on Sunday that they will continue serving as an MP for Brighton Pavilion and intends to "devote even more of my work to the political arena." They were elected as the first solo leader for the English and Welsh party in 2008 after the system of having two principal speakers was abandoned. They first became an MP in the 2010 general election. The individual announced that they are stepping down as leader to make way for a new Green Party leader, stating that their decision is to allow others to gain recognition, build a profile within the party, and potentially run for office. In their statement, they acknowledged the party's recent successes, including their first Westminster seat, first local council, and share of the vote in the most recent election.

Corrie McKeague, 23, a gunner stationed at RAF Honington in Suffolk, disappeared after a night out in Bury St Edmunds early on September 24. His mother, Nicola Urquhart, told the BBC's Victoria Derbyshire program, "Nobody can just disappear." She added that it would be in character for McKeague to get into a stranger's car. The last known sighting of McKeague was on CCTV footage of him walking alone and eating takeout food in Bury St Edmunds at 03:20 BST on September 24. A trace on his mobile phone showed it was in Bury St Edmunds early on September 24, but later moved to the Barton Mills area. For more updates on this story, visit BBC Suffolk Live Ms. Urquhart said the phone data suggests that the journey took 28 minutes, which is "how long it would take to drive [between the two places]." It is not known whether the phone was still active or not.

A teacher, Regina Hungerford, 56, denied hitting a 17-year-old student who was listening to music in her class at Merthyr Tydfil College. However, a disciplinary panel ruled that there was likely contact with the student and her conduct was deemed "unacceptable." The Education Workforce Council subsequently imposed a suspension, stating that the public interest lies in her being able to teach again. Mrs. Hungerford admitted to shouting and slamming a book on the teen's desk, who was described as "provocative and disruptive," while listening to rap music in class. She maintained that she never struck the student's head.

After being cleared of a criminal charge for assaulting the student during a math lesson for those with learning difficulties, a disciplinary panel found that there was a balance of probabilities that Mrs. Hungerford had made physical contact with the student's head or hand. The panel concluded that her actions were inappropriate.

Morecambe bought the Jensen Interceptor in 1968 and kept it in his garage. In 2014, it was sold to an auction house. The buyer, Silverstone Auctions, contracted Jensen specialists, Cropredy Bridge, to restore the car's engine, brakes, and bodywork. Morecambe, who died in 1984, was the sole owner of the car. It was first produced at Jensen's factory in West Bromwich on September 23, 1968. Read more about this and other stories on Silverstone Auctions' dedicated website, which includes comments from Morecambe's chauffeur, Mike Fountain, who sometimes drove the comedian and his wife in the Jensen. However, as the car is a two-seater, there was not enough room for a third person. Fountain said that Morecambe would often end up "screwed up in the back" of the Jensen, but it was still his favorite car.

Recently, N Srinivasan stepped down temporarily from his position as the head of the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) following a ruling by the Supreme Court. He owns a team in the IPL, which is considered the richest cricket tournament in the world. He is widely regarded as the most powerful cricket administrator globally. In February, he was elected as the chairman of cricket's world governing body, the International Cricket Council, and is set to assume the role in July. Last month, Sunil Gavaskar, a former India captain and batting legend, was appointed as the interim head of the cricket board. The Supreme Court has ordered that a panel be appointed to investigate the charges against Srinivasan and 12 others, including some players. The court stated that it cannot ignore the allegations of corruption.

In a peaceful and somber procession, some participants were affected by the recent suicide bombings on Belgium's airport and metro station, which resulted in the tragic loss of 32 lives. A Belgian broadcaster described the event as "calm and silent." The march was initially scheduled to take place a week after the 22nd of March attacks, but it was postponed due to security concerns. The participants included relatives of the victims, paramedics, and airport staff, as well as individuals from various religious backgrounds. They carried flowers as a tribute to those who were lost in the attacks. The procession traveled through the Molenbeek neighborhood, where many of the alleged attackers in both Brussels and Paris resided. The march concluded outside the city's stock exchange with a makeshift memorial. One of the organizers of the event, Hassan Bousetta, expressed the importance of standing up against such cowardly attacks, showing solidarity with fellow citizens.

If approved, UEFA's plan to have an additional assistant referee positioned behind each goal will remain in place. The governing body discussed this issue on Friday and announced that a final decision will be made in January. Goal-line technology was introduced in the Premier League for the 2013-14 season and was also used at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil by FIFA. During a press conference in Paris, UEFA General Secretary Gianni Infantino expressed a positive attitude towards the implementation of the system, despite logistical challenges. He stated that if the system is adopted for Euro 2016, it will also be implemented for the club competitions for the upcoming season, including the Champions League and Europa League. This would be in addition to the five existing assistant referees. The final decision will be made by the executive committee in January, but the initial response from the committee has been positive.

The company announced that net profit for the period was 45.6 million Australian dollars (equivalent to $32.4 million; £22.7 million), representing a 56.7% increase compared to the same period last year. According to the company, this positive result was due to "organic growth" and the fact that it managed to overcome the current global economic conditions. On Wednesday, the pizza giant also announced its second profit upgrade in December, leading to a more than 10% increase in its shares. Domino's Australia is listed in Sydney and is officially known as Domino's Pizza Enterprises. The company holds the master franchise rights to the Domino's brand in Australia, Belgium, France, Germany, Japan, and The Netherlands. The firm reported a significant increase in its operations in Japan, with 48 new stores opened in six months to December. Its Australia and New Zealand operations are also on track to open more than 50 new stores.

In the thrilling final match, Stokes faced four consecutive sixes from Carlos Brathwaite in the last over. Despite this setback, Cook praised Stokes as an exceptional talent and cricketer. He expressed confidence in Stokes' ability to handle the situation, stating that he is the type of character who can still score a remarkable 250 in a Test match. The dramatic hitting was exceptional, and while Stokes would have preferred a different start, the second ball was still impressive, traveling 94 meters back. Cook, deeply disappointed by England's loss, acknowledged the overall success of the tournament, but couldn't help but feel disheartened by the unfortunate outcome in the final over.

There is speculation that the individual may have consumed heroin, possibly mixed with fentanyl or carfentanyl, both significantly more potent than street heroin. The authorities reported that a man was discovered unresponsive at a residence in the village of Fitzwilliam, near Wakefield, on Sunday, and later passed away in the hospital. A 43-year-old man has been taken into custody in relation to this event. More information on local news from across Yorkshire is provided by Det Ch Insp Stuart Spencer of West Yorkshire Police. He emphasized, "We are strongly advising regular heroin users and those who purchase drugs from street suppliers to exercise extreme caution regarding the substances they are taking." A warning of "potentially fatal batches" of the drug has been issued after multiple fatalities in Hull, Barnsley, Leeds, and Normanton, in West Yorkshire. In March, Cleveland Police linked six deaths to a single batch of heroin in Stockton-on-Tees. Last week, a joint investigation was launched after a similar situation in another region.

A Masai Graham won with a joke that said, "My dad told me to sign up for a donor card, he's a man after my own heart." The funniest jokes were chosen by a panel of 10 judges before being shared with 2,000 people who voted for their favorites. Tim Vine, Stewart Francis, and Zoe Lyon have won this competition before, organized by TV channel Dave. Graham, from West Bromwich, won after making it onto the shortlist in both 2014 and 2015. He said, "It's a great honor to win Joke of the Fringe. Not bad for someone from West Brom!" Stuart Mitchell, a comedian, was second in the voting with a joke about why old people say, "there's no place like home," even when they're in one. The judges listened to an average of 60 different comedy acts before selecting their favorites.

A 31-year-old woman named Erika Murray was taken into custody on a Thursday evening after a concerned neighbor notified the police about the safety of other children in the residence. Detectives discovered the bodies inside a squalid and vermin-infested home. The following day, Ms. Murray pleaded not guilty to charges including foetal death concealment, witness intimidation, and permitting substantial injury to a child. Her attorney expressed that he believed she suffered from a mental health condition, stating, "In situations like this, mental illness doesn't always provide clear answers." The police were initially called to the residence in Blackstone after a ten-year-old boy approached a neighbor and inquired, "How do you make a baby stop crying?"

Jack Whitley was the goalkeeper for the Blues during their first season in the top flight, playing for Chelsea between 1907 and 1914. Before his passing, he requested to be laid to rest in Brompton Cemetery, even though he no longer resided in London. The Chelsea Supporters' Trust has initiated a crowdfunding campaign to erect a gravestone for Whitley, as it is believed his widow could not afford a marked grave. Chelsea's official historian, Rick Glanvill, believes that a headstone would be "a significant gesture" and that "the connection between the club and the cemetery is unique, with a football ground situated next to it."

A multi-talented player, 24 years old, left the field with his arm in a sling after attempting a diving catch in Sharjah. The incident occurred when the player, named Stokes, was fielding at backward square leg and dove in an attempt to catch Sarfraz Ahmed off bowler Samit Patel. According to England pace bowler Stuart Broad, "as soon as he hit the ground, we knew he was in trouble." Although the injury is a concern, the team has the batting and bowling strength to compensate if the player cannot participate further. After receiving treatment, the player left the field using his shirt as a makeshift sling and appeared in obvious discomfort. "No one likes to see a player get injured," Broad added.

In April 2014, Boko Haram abducted 276 girls from their school in Chibok, and later released 21 of them in October after negotiations with the Red Cross. These girls were taken into government custody but were brought home for Christmas. However, family members reported that the girls were forced to stay in a politician's house, prohibited from going home, and prevented from attending church services with their families. The girls were taken to an assembly member's house in Chibok to be reunited with their parents, but were not allowed to go home. Some parents expressed their frustration, saying, "I can't believe my daughter has come this close to home but can't come home." One parent added, "There's no point bringing them to Chibok only to be locked in another prison. They couldn't even go to church on Christmas Day." Another parent mentioned that a soldier had confiscated his phone when he tried to take a picture of his daughter.

Banjong Pongphon was a significant suspect in the investigation and had significant influence in the region, according to the police. The UN refugee agency announced that 25,000 migrants boarded people smugglers' boats from Myanmar and Bangladesh in the first quarter of 2015, which is twice the number who left during the same period in 2014. Banjong Pongphon is the mayor of Padang Besar, a sub-district in southern Songkhla province where 26 bodies were discovered in mass graves last week. According to a report by the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), smugglers' camps in the forests and plantations surrounding Padang Besar are one of the main destinations for these migrants. The cause of death for those who were exhumed from the graves in Songkhla remains unclear. According to the UNHCR report, more than half of the migrants who boarded the people smugglers' boats in the first quarter of 2015 were children.

The body representing 1,000 county officers has taken out ads on buses and in local papers to warn that traditional policing methods may be abandoned due to the loss of 153 officers in Wiltshire Police since 2010. Despite cuts, Chief Constable Mike Veale acknowledges the impact but assures the force's commitment to local policing. The federation's Cuts Have Consequences campaign highlights that Wiltshire Police currently has the lowest number of officers per member of the public in the UK, and with a 16% reduction in the workforce, there are not enough officers to respond to emergencies, leaving communities unsafe at night and enabling drink-driving offenses to go unpunished. The force has had to cut £17 million from its budget, and there are still an estimated £10 million in cuts to come. Federation Chairman Mike White states that 80% of policing funds are allocated to staff wages, and the force has had to make significant budget reductions to balance its financials.

On January 30, 1915, England and Scotland played a charity match organized by former England international and Northampton Saints captain, Edgar Mobbs. The objective of the match was to recruit athletes for Mobbs' World War I battalion. The commemorative match will take place on January 24, 2015, at Olney Rugby Club. The event will feature players from the East Midlands region facing off against The 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment, while Olney Ladies will compete against the Army Women's XV.

Edgar Mobbs was born in Northampton in 1882. He played his early career in Olney and became captain of Northampton Rugby Football Club in 1907. The walk-in service is designed to reduce doctor appointments and curb the excessive use of antibiotics, according to NHS England. The UK's international terrorism threat level has remained severe, or high, since August 2014, indicating an elevated likelihood of an attack. The poll found that 43% of respondents believed there should be more specialized firearm officers, while 26% felt all officers should be routinely armed. A smaller percentage, 12%, stated that they would never carry a firearm under any circumstances. Out of the total police ranks, 2,139 authorized firearms officers represent 6.7%. Between March 2015 and March 2016, there were 3,974 police firearms operations. During the same period, there were seven incidents in which police firearms were discharged. The poll also showed strong support for Tasers, with 75% of respondents indicating that all officers should have access to them. While the presence of armed police is a necessary precaution, it has raised questions regarding public safety and security.

Thomas, 28, is a crucial member of Team Sky's squad trying to aid Chris Froome in securing a second successive Tour title. Froome has already had an X-ray after a crash during the fourth stage of the Tour de France. "On the cobbles, it's already a bit hazardous. If it does rain, it could put an end to someone's race quite easily," said Thomas. "You train all year for this and to have it end like that would be devastating for whoever it was," he added. "So, let's hope it stays dry and everyone stays out of trouble." Froome touched wheels in the peloton and fell just five kilometers into the 163.5km fourth stage between Le Touquet-Paris-Place and Lille Metropole. The 29-year-old suffered a grazed left hip and wrist injury, before quickly getting back on his bike and rejoining the peloton, after receiving medical attention from the race doctor. He is currently in seventh place overall, two seconds behind race leader Vincenzo Nibali, following stage four's victory by Marcel Kittel.

The case involves a Virginia public school district trying to prevent a 17-year-old transgender female student from using the boys' bathroom. The justices are expected to rule on the case before the end of June. The high court is one justice short due to the death of Antonin Scalia, which could lead to a 4-4 decision. Schools districts nationwide are divided on whether to require transgender students to use bathrooms corresponding with the sex listed on their birth certificates. The justices accepted a petition from Gloucester County, Virginia, ruling that the school board was not required to comply with a lower court's order that transgender student Gavin Grimm should be allowed to use the boys' bathroom. Gavin, who was born female but identifies as male, came out as a transgender boy during his freshman year of high school. He sued the school board.

The leader of Comhairle nan Eilean Siar, Angus Campbell, pointed out that the airline offering flights on the route had lower prices to Algarve than Stornoway. Over 11,000 people have supported a Facebook campaign for the lower fares. Loganair, a company that flies the island routes for Flybe, has defended their pricing structure. They explained that discounts are offered to children, students, people visiting family members in the hospital, and residents of the islands. Mr. Campbell said that reducing the cost of air travel is a priority for the Our Islands Our Future project, which aims to grant more powers to councils in Shetland, Orkney, and the Western Isles. He added that many islanders have questioned why the fares are so high. He continued by providing an example, stating that a flight from Stornoway to Glasgow for Wednesday and returning on Thursday would cost a total of £351 on the Flybe website.

Cleveland Police, as reported by the Northern Echo, allegedly monitored the activities of six people following a 2012 article on the front page. This involved reporters from the paper, a staff member, and a solicitor, according to the Echo. The force has not commented on the matter for BBC. A complaint has been filed with the Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) by the Police Federation. The force allegedly used the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act (RIPA), which governs surveillance related to crime or public safety concerns, to identify the whistleblower. According to the Echo, an application was made after the story was published, which was based on an internal force report about institutionalized racism within the force. A Cleveland Police spokeswoman told the paper that she could neither confirm nor deny whether a RIPA application was made to monitor the phone activity of three of its journalists, a serving police officer, a solicitor, and the then-chairman of Cleveland Police Federation. The editor of the Northern Echo, Peter, was not available for comment at the time of publication.

A study of employees and managers found that 25% of new fathers took no paternity leave at all. Only 9% took more than the two-week statutory leave. The research conducted by the Institute of Leadership & Management (ILM) attributed this to entrenched attitudes among employers and concerns among new fathers that they could not afford to take leave. The government announced last year plans to allow parents to share their maternity and paternity leave, with changes scheduled for April 2015. However, the ILM stated that the changes would not have a significant impact unless employer attitudes were also addressed. According to Charles Elvin, ILM's chief executive, the introduction of shared parental leave is crucial in enabling more women to progress into senior roles, yet the study revealed that cultural barriers are hindering the uptake of both statutory and additional paternity leave. Elvin noted that there remains a cultural expectation within organizations that women, rather than men, will take leave.

On March 14th, a helicopter from the Irish Coastguard Rescue team, which had four people on board, went down. Sadly, Capt. Dara Fitzpatrick was rescued from the sea, but she later passed away. The search continues for the bodies of her fellow crew members. Divers were waiting until Friday due to bad weather. Supt. Tony Healy of the Irish Police said that the divers on the seabed are currently working hard and will stop after their diving cycle, but will not dive in darkness. He also mentioned their main goal is to recover the crew members. Chief Inspector J�rgen Whyte of the IAAIU said they found a data recorder at 16:30 on the seabed near Blackrock. Mr. Whyte said the recorder will be taken to Dublin before being sent to the UK air accident investigation branch, where it will be prepared for further study.

More than 130,000 individuals have experienced the exhibition since its debut in October. The exhibit includes The Lacemaker, considered Vermeer's smallest piece, that was borrowed from The Louvre and is being displayed in the UK for the first time. To accommodate the high demand, the museum is extending its opening hours during the final two weeks of the exhibition. The popularity of the exhibition, Vermeer's Women: Secrets and Silence, is believed to be attributed to the presence of The Lacemaker. Curator Betsy Wiseman stated, "The Louvre seldom lends this painting, as it is nearly as significant in their collection as the Mona Lisa." The exhibit also showcases A Lady at the Virginals with a Gentleman (The Music Lesson), borrowed from The Royal Collection, and A Young Woman Seated at a Virginal, from the National Gallery in London.

Helen Bailey, a 51-year-old woman, was found dead in a cesspit at her house in Royston, Hertfordshire, in July 2016. She had not been seen since April 11. Bailey's fiance, Ian Stewart, denies being responsible for her death. Edward Farmer initially told St Albans Crown Court that he saw Bailey in a car in Broadstairs, Kent, between mid-April and June. However, later he admitted that the sighting could have been weeks earlier. During the trial, Farmer claimed to have seen Bailey on Charlotte Street near her holiday home in the town, driving a dark-colored Range Rover or a vehicle similar to that type. He stated that she was alone, despite defense claims that she had been kidnapped by two violent men who had taken her to Broadstairs. When questioned about the date of the alleged sighting, Mr. Farmer said it was "about five, maybe six weeks prior to the police interview."

Minutes from the central bank's meeting in October reveal that officials were concerned about market fluctuations and economic challenges in other regions. However, they were cautious not to convey this message as it may have created a negative perception. Overall, the officials maintained confidence in the US economy's stability. This belief led to the decision to discontinue the stimulus program, known as quantitative easing (QE), in which the central bank bought bonds to maintain low long-term interest rates and stimulate spending. As per the meeting minutes, members agreed that the broader economy's underlying strength was sufficient to support steady progress towards full employment. Consequently, the Fed chose to end the QE program. Following the announcement, US stock markets exhibited a muted response, with the Dow Jones Index briefly fluctuating before closing in the red for the day. Nonetheless, the central bank demonstrated its commitment to maintaining its established course by providing reassurance to investors.

Robin Waistell claimed that he was unable to sell his property in Maesteg due to the rail body's failure to address the invasive weed infestation on the bank behind his home. This case may serve as a precedent for homeowners who have their properties negatively impacted by knotweed on railway embankments. Network Rail announced that it would be carefully reviewing the court's decision. However, it has been reported that the rail infrastructure body was denied the opportunity to appeal the ruling immediately. As a result, Network Rail may face significant legal costs, possibly reaching six figures, after losing the case brought by Mr. Waistell and his neighbor. Mr. Waistell, a 70-year-old widower, had relocated to the bungalow from Spain in the hopes of basking in the sun once more. Unfortunately, his property sale was delayed due to the knotweed infestation on adjacent Network Rail land, and he is now seeking a resolution to this ongoing issue.

During his confirmation hearing, Rex Tillerson made some statements that might escalate tensions with Beijing. Beijing has been constructing artificial islands on reefs, which also overlap with the claims of other nations. Recent images indicate the presence of military defenses on some of the islands, as stated by a think tank. During his appearance before the US Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Tillerson compared China's island-building to Russia's annexation of Crimea from Ukraine. He expressed that the US would need to send a clear message to China: first, stop building islands and second, restrict access to those islands. This island-building has generated discontent in the region, as China claims almost all of the South China Sea, but is opposed by neighboring countries like Vietnam, the Philippines, Taiwan, Malaysia, and Brunei. In July, an international tribunal sided with the Philippines' case against China's claims, but Beijing said they would not respect the ruling.

The news is about index-linked bonds possibly coming soon, but it depends on market conditions. The council has already become the first in Scotland to receive a credit rating, with Moody's Investors Service giving them an Aa2 issuer credit rating. This funding will support a £1bn capital program. The council leader, Jennifer Laing, said that a bond issue could be a big deal for the city and that it would be a first for a Scottish local authority. She also mentioned that being proactive with capital funding shows their commitment to protecting the revenue budget, which is important for delivering services.

Media playback is not supported on this device. In Chicago, Gwen Jorgensen led the pack with American Jorgensen not far behind. Jorgensen secured her second successive world title with a 15th consecutive win. "It's been tough to meet the criteria, and I've been sweating it out," remarked Wales' former world champion, Stanford. Holland stated, "Finishing on the podium was a win for me. I just had to stay with Jorgensen." Jorgensen finished the 1.5km swim, 40km cycle, and 10km run in a total time of one hour, 55 minutes, and 36 seconds.

GMB Scotland asserts that the conditions of its members in the offshore sector are being targeted. The organization's officers will request authorization from the union's regional committee to poll members who are covered under the Offshore Contractors Agreement about potential strike actions. Unite has made a similar move recently. Several oil and gas companies in the North Sea have announced plans to cut jobs and reduce salaries, following a sustained decline in oil prices. This move by GMB Scotland follows failed negotiations between the two unions and the Offshore Contractors Association (OCA), the body representing offshore contractors, which took place on Friday. The Offshore Contractors Agreement safeguards workers in mechanical, electrical, and allied services, construction, maintenance, design, project engineering, fabrication, and decommissioning. GMB Scotland regional officer, John Kelly, stated, "We're witnessing blatant opportunism on the part of some oil companies and contractors as they attempt to fundamentally undermine the terms and conditions of our members."

The Saddlers looked to be the superior team in the first half, with Jon McLaughlin of Burton making crucial saves to keep the game level. Burton came close to scoring through Stuart Beavon, but his shot went off the post. Wigan's win over Bury reduced Albion's lead at the top to two points, while Walsall maintained their fourth-place position. Burton Albion manager Nigel Clough stated to BBC Radio Derby that the game was not likely to be an open, free-flowing classic, adding that the team played better on Monday but focused on their strong defensive play. Walsall head coach Sean O'Driscoll also commented on the game.

The Prime Minister raised the issue during a discussion with U.S. President Barack Obama at the White House. Critics of existing rules argue that they make it easier for U.S. authorities to extradite UK nationals, as they require less evidence to support their case. However, a senior judge reviewed the issue in 2011 and determined it was fair to British citizens. The BBC's political editor, Nick Robinson, reported that the Prime Minister raised concerns about the practical operation of extradition rules during a two-hour meeting at the White House during the Prime Minister's three-day official visit to the United States. Concerns have been raised about the 2003 U.S.-UK extradition treaty following controversial cases involving British citizens, such as Christopher Tappin and Gary McKinnon. Parliament's Joint Committee on Human Rights has urged the government to renegotiate the treaty, stating it is unbalanced.

In Fiscal Combat, the player takes on the role of Mr. Melenchon as he navigates the city streets, battling against oligarchs and other political rivals. The objective is to gather funds from the wealthy to finance Melenchon's policies. The player's challenge is to accumulate as much money as possible while evading attempts by the wealthy to harm them. Among the adversaries Melenchon must face are former President Nicolas Sarkozy, the head of the IMF, Christine Lagarde; tax-dodging politician Jerome Cahuzac; and L'Oreal heiress Liliane Bettencourt. Additionally, Melenchon must defeat presidential rivals Emmanuel Macron and Francois Fillon. According to Le Monde, the game was developed by Melenchon supporters who met on the 18-25 chatroom of Jeuxvideo.com, a French gaming website. Since its creation, the game has been fully embraced by the candidate himself, who has utilized it as a means of engaging with the public and showcasing his policies.

The proposed merger between Bouygues Telecom and Vivendi-owned SFR would create the largest mobile phone service provider in France. This consolidation would reduce the number of mobile phone companies in the country to just three. In a similar development, Altice, the company owning French cable TV operator Numericable, has also made an offer for SFR, but has not disclosed the amount offered. Bouygues Telecom and SFR are France's second and third largest mobile phone companies, and their merger would surpass Orange to become the largest mobile phone company in the country. Before the deal can be completed, both French and European Union competition regulators must approve it. A similar situation has already raised competition concerns in Brussels with the Telefonica acquisition of E-Plus in Germany. Industry analysts have suggested that the Bouygues offer is indicative of a broader trend of consolidation among mobile phone companies worldwide.

Doreen Collyer, a former University of Chester lecturer, was diving in Perth on Sunday when she encountered an unfortunate incident. It is believed that the 60-year-old was killed by a great white shark measuring 16 feet in length, as reported by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Her husband, David Collyer, described her as a "beautiful person" and a "loving wife." The couple had relocated to Australia from Neston, Cheshire, about five years ago. Mrs. Collyer held an advanced open water diving certification. According to the report, her diving partner managed to bring her up from the water but was unable to save her as she succumbed to her injuries at the scene. Prof. Annette McIntosh-Scott, a University of Chester professor, said that Mrs. Collyer was a "hugely valued and loved member of staff" and had served the Faculty of Health and Social Care for 15 years. She was remembered as a dedicated educator and healthcare professional, with her students being at the core of her teaching efforts.

A native American bird was recently discovered in England, believed to have been blown across the Atlantic by Hurricane Gert while migrating to South America. Martin Cade of Portland Bird Observatory expressed his amazement at the rare find. This species is common in the US and is known for its annual migrations between North and South America. It is thought that the bird may have been caught up in storms while crossing the Caribbean and blown across to Europe with a strong tailwind. Another sighting of the bird was reported on Mizen Head in Ireland. The bird, about the size of a robin, was seen feeding well and appeared active. It is likely that the bird will feed up before heading south to Spain and Africa. Birdwatchers came from as far as the Midlands, South Wales, and Yorkshire when news of the bird's arrival spread on Monday.

The 28-year-old Chilean international scored a crucial goal in the FA Cup semi-final against Manchester City. With just one year remaining on his Arsenal contract, the player has yet to sign a new deal. Manager Arsène Wenger stated, "I don't think you would sell him to any Premier League club, that is for sure," expressing confidence in the player's stay. However, Wenger has not yet confirmed his own future with Arsenal, where he is focused on identifying transfer targets for the upcoming season. Though he is out of contract at the end of the current season, Wenger has been offered a two-year extension. He explained, "I work until the last day of the season for the present and future," emphasizing the importance of transfer targets for the club's success.

Gene Palmer is the second person detained for his involvement in the prison break. Joyce Mitchell has already been charged with helping the prisoners escape. Richard Matt and David Sweat used power tools to break out of the Clinton Correctional Facility. A large-scale search is ongoing to locate the duo, who are both convicted murderers. Mr. Palmer is being held on bail, having appeared before a judge on charges of trafficking contraband in prison, tampering with evidence, and misconduct. His attorney, Andrew Brockway, admitted that his client provided the meat, but claimed he was unaware that it contained the tools or that the prisoners intended to escape. "He did pass the hamburger meat," said Mr. Brockway. "He shouldn't have done it. He apologizes for it. His client plans to plead not guilty," he added. Clinton County District Attorney Andrew Wylie stated that Ms. Mitchell had facilitated the escape by placing the tools in the meat.

The H3 project integrates back office services for four police, fire, and local council authorities in Hampshire and Oxfordshire. The aim is to save up to £5 million per year. However, the Police Federation has criticized the project, stating that payroll mistakes have occurred since its inception in 2014. Hampshire's Police and Crime Commissioner (PCC) has said that the investment will result in improvements by May. A report to the PCC has revealed that H3 has caused issues with recruitment, staff management, and staff sickness. Additionally, the system has burdened police officers with excessive back office tasks, which hinders their efficiency. In February 2016, 1,300 officers received incorrect pay, and some allowances were inaccurately calculated in March 2016. The BBC also reported in 2015 that payment delays to Hampshire County Council's suppliers had tripled under the new system. The chairman of the Hampshire Police Federation, John Apter, has expressed concerns about the system.

On Thursday, two young men, aged 22 from Sleaford and 25 from Bracknell, were apprehended by law enforcement. It is believed that the pair were engaged in repeated attempts to breach the security of the Microsoft network between January and March this year. Both individuals have been charged under the UK's Computer Misuse Act, which makes it illegal to access computers without authorization. Police have stated that the two were part of a larger group that was planning to infiltrate Microsoft's systems and steal customer data. The raids were conducted by detectives from the South East Regional Organised Crime Unit (Serocu) who also confiscated devices that were believed to have been used in the cyber intrusion.

At the competition, 20-year-old Jutanugarn demonstrated remarkable skill by staying on course and making six birdies. Her impressive performance put her within striking distance of the tournament's record-breaking score of 19-under par. However, South Korea's Mirim Lee, who had led after the first and second rounds, slipped to second place with a score of 69. Scotland's Catriona Matthew is now six shots back in fourth place. Jutanugarn has an opportunity to make history as the first Thai to win a major tournament, but she must navigate her way through the final round. She narrowly missed out on the ANA Inspiration earlier this season by bogeying her final three holes, but she has learned from that experience and is determined to control what she can. When speaking with BBC Sport, Jutanugarn displayed poise and consistency and said, "I know how to play under pressure. I need to focus on what is within my control."

Delivering a speech at an IMF gathering in Washington, she stated, "It is evident that the approach taken in the UK has been effective." Mrs. Lagarde downplayed the discrepancies between the IMF's forecast of future deficits and the more optimistic estimate presented by the Office for Budget Responsibility. She explained that the figures were nearly identical, only calculated differently. George Osborne and German finance minister Wolfgang Schaeuble were among the panel participants when she made these remarks. "Typically, during an election year, the teams that provide the projections for future deficits tend to err on the side of caution, assuming that whatever is announced is not necessarily or inevitably going to happen," she said. Mrs. Lagarde added that the UK authorities had managed to strike the right balance between spending cuts and revenue increases. "It is clearly also producing results, as evidenced by the comparative growth rates achieved by various European countries," she concluded.

Transport for London (TfL) is considering implementing a new set of regulations, which would require an English language test, a map-reading assessment, a fixed landline, and the ability to book rides seven days in advance. Uber has expressed concern, stating that these measures would make their service less popular. Black cab drivers have argued that stricter regulations are needed. Recent protests outside City Hall have put pressure on city legislators. Uber's app connects riders with nearby drivers using GPS technology, providing an estimated fare. It typically offers lower prices than traditional firms and relies on technology for navigation. Transactions are cashless and are conducted using pre-registered bank details. TfL says the consultation aims to "raise standards across the industry" as the private hire industry has experienced exponential growth and technology advancements. Uber claims that if these proposals are implemented, prices will increase and congestion will worsen.

These devoted music festival enthusiasts, on average spending £581 annually, often opt for premium tickets or upgraded camping packages. More male-dominated than other consumers, they are also more likely to purchase music on CD or as downloads. The data comes from a survey of 504 UK residents who attended at least one festival in the previous year. According to Eventbrite, the ticketing website that commissioned the survey, these superfans play a significant role in driving the music festival market, often recommending events and music to their friends. These devoted fans make up 28% of the festival-going audience, with 54% of them stating they would attend an event alone. They spend an average of £45 more per event than casual fans, yet their loyalty is not guaranteed, as 46% feel that festivals are becoming too corporate. There are over 100 music festivals held in the UK each year, ranging from the well-known Glastonbury and T in the Park events to smaller gatherings.

Sterling experienced a 1.86% increase against the dollar, reaching $1.3240, and a 1.73% increase against the euro, amounting to €1.1957. The FTSE 100 share index reached new 11-month highs before dropping back and closing almost unchanged at 6,680.69, down 2.17 points or 0.03%. The more UK-focused FTSE 250 index increased by 68.75 points, or 0.4%, reaching 16,775.14. The property sector, which experienced a sharp sell-off immediately following the Brexit vote, received a boost from Galliford Try. The housebuilder stated that it still expects full-year profits to be in line with expectations, causing its shares to rise by 8.5%. Financial stocks, another victim of the post-referendum sell-off, also had a better day. Shares in insurer Aviva increased by 4.26% while Lloyds Banking Group's shares saw a rise of 4.26%.

In April, a boat named the MV Karen got some serious damage after a submarine caught its fishing nets and pulled it back 18 miles from the County Down coast. The boat's captain said that his crew was lucky to escape without injuries, but fixing the boat would cost around £10,000. It turns out that a British submarine was involved in the incident. The Ministry of Defence (MoD) initially said they don't comment on submarine activities. However, new information revealed that a UK submarine caused the damage to the MV Karen. The Royal Navy said that the submarine didn't recognize the boat as a fishing vessel with nets in the water.

Kian Delos Santos was shot by police officers who claimed he was involved in the drug trade and had resisted arrest. However, surveillance footage appears to show plainclothes officers dragging him away. Evidence suggests that Kian was kneeling and facedown when he was killed. Hundreds of mourners attended his funeral in Manila, with some holding signs calling for an end to President Duterte's violent drug campaign. The campaign has received support from many people who are tired of drug-related crime in the Philippines. Nuns, priests, and hundreds of children chanted "justice for Kian, justice for all" as they joined the procession from the church to the cemetery where Kian was buried, according to a report from the Reuters news agency. His father, Saldy, briefly spoke during the Mass to insist on his son's innocence and express his anger towards the police. "Don't they have a heart?" he asked, his voice breaking with emotion. "I'm not sure they do. There are many churches, they should go there."

Construction of a new roadway, which is adjacent to part of an existing canal, began less than a year ago. The 72 km (44 mile) route permits two-way traffic and accommodates larger vessels. Several container ships from around the world successfully navigated the route on Saturday as part of a trial run. Helicopters and naval vessels were involved in the security operation. The Sinai Peninsula borders the canal and serves as a base for Islamic militants who have killed hundreds of people since the military overthrew President Mohammed Morsi in 2013. The Suez Canal, which opened almost 150 years ago, connects the Mediterranean with the Red Sea. Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi said that the expansion of one of the world's busiest shipping routes will increase trade and create jobs across the country. The canal currently handles 7% of global sea-borne trade.

In Leeds Crown Court, it was reported that James Carragher was sentenced to seven years in prison in 1993 and 14 years in 2004 for sex offenses. He denies 50 charges of indecent assault committed at St. William's Home in Market Weighton, East Riding of Yorkshire, between the 1970s and 1990s. Two former staff members were also tried earlier for the same allegations. The home, which catered to troubled boys, was run by the De La Salle Catholic order and has since closed. Carragher, who served as head of the home from 1976 to 1990, along with two other men, is accused of abusing 19 former students between them. During the opening statement for the prosecution, Richard Wright QC said that Carragher was a man who "had a committed sexual interest in children and young boys in particular." Mr. Wright added, "He hid behind a cloak of respectability."

A 23-year-old player recently signed a three-year contract with the team after joining for an undisclosed fee. He came from Vitoria Setubal and is excited to adapt to his new country and way of life. He believes he will be successful and is committed to giving his best to help the team win. The player is a former Portuguese Under-21 international who had 23 appearances for Vitoria Setubal last season, before moving to the club from Benfica. In addition to him, another Portuguese center-back, Bruno Alves, joined the team from Cagliari, making it the second Portuguese player to join this summer. Another player, Dalcio, joined on loan from Benfica to play as a midfielder at Ibrox.

Long-time Mugabe critic Morgan Tsvangirai, along with former Vice-President Joice Mujuru, has announced their intentions to collaborate during the upcoming election next year. However, it remains uncertain which of them will stand as the presidential candidate. Mugabe, aged 93, has been in power since Zimbabwe's independence from Britain in 1980, and has declared his intention to contest the elections again. Tsvangirai said during a press conference, "This is just the beginning of the building blocks towards establishing a broad alliance to confront Zanu-PF between now and the next election." This alliance is the crucial first step towards uniting a deeply divided opposition, and if successful, it would mark the first time since 1980 that President Mugabe has faced a united opposition on such a scale.

On Wednesday, Jean-Claude Juncker met with a group of MEPs. Mr. Juncker shared that he values democratic expressions and will respect the decision of Scotland. Regarding Catalonia's EU membership, he clarified that one cannot join the EU merely by sending a letter. In response to a question about the Scottish independence referendum, Jean-Claude Juncker stated that he supports democratic processes, but he will not preempt the outcome. He reaffirmed that an independent Scotland would have the opportunity to remain in the EU. During another meeting, Mr. Juncker was asked by David Coburn, the UKIP MEP representing Scotland, about the potential membership of an independent Scotland in the EU. Mr. Juncker confirmed that this would ultimately depend on the UK's decision.

Some students posted mean jokes about hurting children, attacking people, and a very bad time that happened a long time ago. Some of the members also used mean words towards people with different backgrounds. People who believe in free speech said that Harvard's punishment was too harsh. We found out about this through a big student newspaper called The Crimson. The mean comments were shared on a Facebook chat group for people who are going to start studying at Harvard this year. This group was made by some students who wanted to share more adult stuff than the main chat room. To join this smaller group, people had to make a mean picture called a "provocative meme" and send it in. When Harvard learned about this group, they started looking into it.

Local leaders from Santa Clara County announced their plan to gather signatures in order to recall Judge Aaron Persky in the upcoming year. Persky came under fire for his lenient sentence in June 2016 when he punished Stanford University swimmer Brock Turner, who was accused of assaulting an unconscious woman behind a dumpster at a fraternity party. The swimmer, who faced up to 14 years in prison, was ultimately handed a six-month sentence, which he served for only three months in county jail after being released. The community leaders, led by law professor Michele Dauber, believe that the residents of Santa Clara County deserve a judge who will protect victims, not rapists. "Women have had enough of rape culture," Dauber stated. "We are determined to take action and hold our judge accountable."

In the annual event, contestants have 5 minutes to tell the most convincing and grandiose lie they can think of. This year's winner, George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria, was surprised to win as he was struggling with a chest infection. In his story, Kemp met with Donald Trump and his wife at an underwater hotel, which he claimed to have bumped into while building a small submarine out of his father's old bubble car. Kemp and his friends took the bubble car on a trip to the Isle of Man, where they encountered other famous personalities inside a submarine made of shortbread tin cans. They then sold these tin submarines to the United States, with the help of Scottish politicians Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond. Last year's winner, Mike Naylor, also known as Monkey Liar, from Wasdale, came in second place, and Helen Jordan came in third. Past winners include comedian and television presenter Sue Perkins.

An investigation revealed that only 28% of Welsh speakers used their language with their general practitioners (GPs), dentists, and opticians. Ms. Huws hopes that her report marks the start of an end to patients' inability to receive healthcare tailored to their needs. Ministers welcomed the report and promised to respond within six months. Based on the experiences of over a thousand Welsh speakers, the inquiry found that 90% of respondents agreed that they should have the right to use their language when interacting with the National Health Service (NHS) regardless of their location in Wales. Other findings included that Welsh speakers who contributed to the inquiry reported feeling awkward and having difficulty explaining their feelings to English-speaking doctors. The report offers 33 recommendations to the Welsh government, calling for ministers to provide a clear policy direction to primary care providers, along with an action plan and a timeline for change.

The proposed bill aims to amend certain aspects of the 2016 Trade Union Act in the UK. This would result in changes to the current restrictions on industrial action in various public sectors, such as the National Health Service (NHS), the fire service, and schools in Wales. The UK government believes that industrial relations are a matter for Westminster. Currently, only strikes supported by 40% of a union's members in a ballot are allowed. However, members of the Welsh Assembly's Equality, Local Government and Communities Committee have agreed that new legislation is necessary to maintain the "social-partnership" approach in Wales. In March, Welsh Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford stated that it would be a "democratic outrage" if ministers in London tried to block the Welsh Trade Union Bill. The Welsh Government argues that UK ministers should not impose restrictions on union activity in devolved services, such as the NHS and schools. The committee report was not supported by one of its eight members, as Conservative AM Janet Finch-Saunders did not agree with the proposal.

On Tuesday, 11-year-old Evha Jannath was on a school trip at Drayton Manor when she fell from a circular boat in Splash Canyon. As a result, Alton Towers, Legoland Windsor, and other amusement parks have temporarily closed similar water-based white knuckle rides. Drayton Manor announced that it would remain closed on Friday for health and safety investigations. 

Merlin Entertainments, which operates Legoland and Alton Towers, stated that they have closed the following rides following the fatal fall at Drayton Manor. The company took immediate action by shutting the rides "on a precautionary basis." They also mentioned that they expect to reopen the rides on Friday. While some sites like Lightwater Valley and West Midland Safari Park have not closed their rides, they remain vigilant in monitoring the situation.

Andy Halliday scored a penalty, and Kenny Miller finished off the scoring to ensure that Rangers claimed the trophy for the fourth time. Their next opponents in the Scottish Cup semi-final will be Celtic. Rangers had struggled in the Challenge Cup, losing to Queen of the South, Raith Rovers, and Alloa Athletic in previous tournaments. Members of the Royal College of Midwives (RCM) plan to stop working for four hours. They voted 9-1 in favor of strike action, marking the first such vote in the college's 134-year history. The Department of Health expressed disappointment and stated that it will collaborate with trusts to ensure a safe service is provided to mothers and babies. The department also emphasized the open door for discussions. The RCM is seeking urgent talks with the health minister to address the dispute. RCM NI director Bredagh Hughes highlighted that midwives are calling for the 1% pay increase granted to their counterparts in Wales, Scotland, and England. "It's crucial for women to understand that this conflict is not with or about them. It's between the department of health and the employers," she added. Hughes assured that no woman will be put at risk, with full emergency coverage in place, and that midwives on the picket line may be called in to supplement staff if necessary.

The number of current account customers affected by the recent fraud incident is less than half the initial 20,000 reported. Fortunately, personal data was not compromised during the attack, and all affected accounts have been fully refunded. Tesco Bank has confirmed it was the target of a sophisticated, well-planned cyber attack over the weekend. The bank has now lifted the suspension on online debit transactions, allowing customers to use their accounts as usual. Current account holders were temporarily restricted from making online payments with their debit cards in order to prevent further illegal activity. The bank has once again expressed their apologies for the inconvenience caused by this issue and assured customers that they are taking steps to prevent similar incidents from happening in the future.

In order to work in the construction industry, individuals must hold a CSCS card, which demonstrates their skills and knowledge of health and safety. However, a joint investigation by BBC London/Newsnight found instances of cheating, with 6,000 card holders required to retake the exam. The CSCS card is widely recognized in the UK as the primary means of certifying builders and is required by major construction firms, as well as Crossrail and Heathrow. The investigation revealed that numerous test centers were offering guaranteed pass for cash, allowing workers without English proficiency to obtain qualifications and access dangerous construction sites. During the investigation, Wep HSE in Ealing was exposed, with its director, Garet Estensen, reading exam answers from a screen. Two other centers were also exposed during the investigation.

The Air Accidents Investigation Branch (AAIB) has published a report on a plane crash that occurred on August 22nd. According to the report, cockpit footage showed the plane responding to the pilot's control inputs. The pilot, Andy Hill, was thrown clear of the aircraft during the crash, and his current condition is serious but stable, being hospitalized. It is unclear whether Mr. Hill initiated his ejection, as the investigation is still ongoing. The report states that the Hawker Hunter's canopy was released at the initial impact, releasing fuel and fuel vapor which then ignited. The jet subsequently split into four parts, with both the pilot and his seat being thrown clear of the cockpit. The AAIB report also mentions that no other factors were found that could have initiated the ejection.

A large area stretching from Bo'ness Harbour to the former Kinneil colliery is set to become a haven for wildlife and plants. It is the second Local Nature Reserve established in the Falkirk Council area. The local authority plans to utilize the reserve status to attract funding to the area. The new status signifies the end of an era for the site, which was utilized for heavy industry until the closure of its central colliery in 1983, marking almost 200 years of industrial use. Parts of the area have already been recognized for their environmental importance. The mudflats and "island" off the foreshore are designated as a Special Protection Area for their conservation value. Councillor Adrian Mahoney, convener of leisure, tourism, and community, welcomed the new status for the Kinneil foreshore, stating, "This year marks the 30th anniversary of the closure of Kinneil Colliery, the last pit in the area, which signifies the end of an era for the site."

In 2013, Spencer Flower, a member of a social housing company, was not considered relevant to a discussion regarding the future of housing in east Dorset. However, he was found guilty of illegal voting due to the potential benefits the company could have received from the passed plan. The Conservative councilor, 72, will remain in public office. Flower, from Verwood, Dorset, was given a six-month conditional discharge and ordered to pay £930 in costs. A district judge at Bournemouth Magistrates' Court ruled that he had violated laws under the Localism Act 2011. Outside the court, Flower did not comment on his political future. He expressed surprise and disappointment at the court's decision, stating that the penalty was minimal and did not involve personal gain or intent.

A representative of the UN, Sigrid Kaag, was speaking as Syria seemed to miss a deadline to remove its arsenal from the country. The goal is to eliminate all chemical weapons by June 30. This plan was created after a sarin rocket attack outside Damascus killed many people last year. The UN and OPCW are overseeing the process of destroying Syria's chemical weapons. Even though the UN has set a deadline of June 30, Damascus had previously pledged to complete the removal of its weapons stockpile by April 27. The majority of the chemical weapons have been moved, but not destroyed, which counts towards the deadline. It is crucial to remove the remaining chemical weapons before the end of the deadline.
